summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) with Hughwon, an electronics technician at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The interview focuses on the failure of the MCC's camera recording system around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019. The witness discusses his knowledge of the system failures, his attempts to repair them, and the institutional culture regarding camera maintenance.

persons.name: Hughwon
persons.context: The primary witness being interviewed. He was the MCC employee responsible for maintaining the camera and recording systems. He details his actions and knowledge regarding the camera system failures in late July and August 2019.

persons.name: Dennis Matulewicz
persons.context: The lead OIG agent conducting the interview. He questions Hughwon about the timeline of camera failures and repair attempts.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose death on August 10, 2019, is the subject of the broader OIG investigation. The camera system failure is significant because it resulted in a lack of recorded video from his unit around the time of his death.

persons.name: SigNet
persons.context: The vendor for the MCC's camera recording system (Nice Vision Pro). Hughwon communicated with their support staff for troubleshooting and instructions.

connections.description: Matulewicz is the OIG agent formally interviewing Hughwon as part of the investigation into Epstein's death and the camera system failure.
Hughwon relied on SigNet for technical support, instructions, and parts for the aging camera recording system at the MCC.

events.title: DVR-2 System Failure
events.description: According to later analysis by SigNet and the FBI, the MCC's DVR-2 camera recording system experienced a catastrophic failure, and no recordings were available after this date. Hughwon recalls working on the system (possibly replacing a motherboard) around this time but was unaware recordings had stopped.

events.title: SIS Discovers Recording Failure
events.description: SIS (Special Investigative Services) personnel discovered they could not review recorded video. Hughwon was notified, called SigNet for instructions, and began seeking replacement hard drives.

events.title: Failed Repair Attempt Due to Access
events.description: Hughwon obtained replacement drives but could not access the DVR room to install them because the staff member with the key (III) was leaving, and he was not allowed to stay in the room alone.

events.title: Epstein's Death and Drive Replacement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell. Hughwon gained access to the DVR room and began replacing two failed hard drives in DVR-2. He warned that replacing the drives would wipe all existing data. The FBI later arrived and seized all the drives from the DVR units.

events.title: New Camera System Installed
events.description: SigNet technicians arrived and, with Hughwon's assistance, installed a new camera recording system that had been on-site but not installed due to lack of priority.

events.title: Hughwon Interviewed by FBI
events.description: Hughwon was previously interviewed by the FBI and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the camera system failures.

locations: OIG New York Field Office, 1 Battery Park Plaza, New York, NY
DVR Room / SIS Room at MCC (described as also containing evidence)
keyFacts: The MCC's camera recording system was over 15 years old, analog, and known to fail frequently. Hughwon states camera failures were a recurring, non-priority issue for MCC management prior to Epstein's death.
Recordings from DVR-2 (which covered half the cameras) stopped on July 29, 2019, due to a system failure, but this was not discovered by staff until August 8, 2019.
Hughwon attempted to repair the system on August 9 but was denied access to the DVR room. He began replacing failed drives on August 10, a process he knew would wipe all prior recorded data.
The FBI seized all hard drives from the DVR units on August 10/11, 2019, as evidence.
A new camera recording system was available on-site for months but was not installed until August 11, 2019, the day after Epstein's death, because it 'was not a priority.'
